items.title: Council works to expand global understanding of U.S. commodities
items.description: The director of industry relations for the U.S. Grains & BioProducts Council says 2026 must be a milestone year for agricultural trade. Ellen Zimmerman tells Brownfield, ‚ÄúEspecially right now when we look at the price of commodities. How can we look at profitability and that bottom line more? Trade is a big part of that […] The post Council works to expand global understanding of U.S. commodities appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: The U.S. Grains & BioProducts Council aims to expand global understanding of U.S. agricultural commodities by 2026. Council director Ellen Zimmerman emphasizes the importance of trade for farmer profitability given current high commodity prices. The Council focuses on improving international understanding of U.S. grains, ethanol, and other agricultural products to boost exports and support farm incomes. Zimmerman states that trade is a crucial component of improving farmer profitability during this period of high commodity prices.

items.title: Improving Waterhemp Control by Managing Spray Water pH
items.description: ST. PAUL, Minn. — Most spray solutions are more than 95% water, yet water quality is rarely considered when herbicide performance comes-up short. The pH of that water and the minerals dissolved in it can directly influence how well an herbicide works once it is sprayed. Certain dissolved cations, such as calcium, magnesium, and iron, […] The post Improving Waterhemp Control by Managing Spray Water pH appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
The study evaluated the effects of spray water pH adjustment on waterhemp control in a corn herbicide program.

Key findings:
- Adding a pH-lowering adjuvant (AlpHa Shot) reduced spray water pH from 7.5 to 5.8
- This pH adjustment improved waterhemp control by 10% at 24 days after treatment (DAT) and 7% at 112 DAT
- Waterhemp density decreased by 64% and biomass was reduced by 55% in the pH-adjusted treatments
- Timing of mixing the pH adjuster (6 days prior vs. at time of spraying) did not affect results
- The benefits of pH adjustment were seen at both full and half rates of the herbicide Acuron GT

The article emphasizes that since most spray solutions are over 95% water, water quality can significantly impact herbicide performance. Acidic or alkaline water, and dissolved minerals, can reduce herbicide effectiveness. Simple water testing and use of pH-buffering adjuvants can help manage these issues.

The advice for applicators is that improving spray water pH is an easy but impactful step to enhance weed control, especially for problem weeds like waterhemp. Proper water conditioning can protect herbicide performance regardless of application timing or herbicide rate.

items.title: U of I Extension Offering Master Naturalist Training
items.description: OREGON, Ill.‚Äî Individuals who are passionate about nature, conservation, and strengthening their communities are invited to apply for the Illinois Master Naturalist Program, now accepting registrations for its Spring 2026 training cohort. Pre‚Äëregistration is required by March 13. Contact Program Coordinator Connie Handel at cahandel@illinois.edu. The Illinois Master Naturalist Program connects residents with the natural world by […] The post U of I Extension Offering Master Naturalist Trai
items.summary:
The University of Illinois Extension is offering Master Naturalist training for the Spring 2026 cohort. Pre-registration is required by March 13. The training will be held on Mondays from 1 to 5 p.m. from March 30 to June 1 at the Kickapoo Mud Creek Nature Conservancy in Oregon, Illinois. There will also be a couple of Saturday field studies. The training is open to adults 18 and up, with a $250 fee. 

The in-person training program covers topics such as botany, climate, forestry, geology, mammals, birds, insects, prairies, and urban and agricultural systems. To become a certified Master Naturalist, applicants must complete additional steps, including an interview, background checks, an online child-protection training, and reference submissions.

Graduates of the program volunteer across a wide range of conservation and education efforts, including managing and restoring natural areas, guiding tours and educational talks, leading youth programs, promoting pollinator conservation, monitoring invasive species, and advocating for community environmental needs. For more information or to request reasonable accommodation, contact Program Coordinator Connie Handel at the provided email address or phone number.

items.title: Pork Cares Farm Impact Reports help protect producers‚Äô future
items.description: A leader with the National Pork Board says protecting producers‚Äô freedom to operate continues to be one of their long-term goals. Jamie Burr, chief sustainability officer, says their organization helps farmers utilize Pork Cares Farm Impact Reports. He says the reports foster valuable supply chain partnerships and elevate pork‚Äôs reputation as both nutritious and planet-friendly. […] The post Pork Cares Farm Impact Reports help protect producers‚Äô future appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: The National Pork Board's Pork Cares Farm Impact Reports help protect pork producers' freedom to operate. Jamie Burr, the Chief Sustainability Officer, states that these reports foster valuable supply chain partnerships and elevate pork's reputation as a nutritious and environmentally-friendly product. The reports aim to safeguard pork producers' ability to operate in the long term.

items.title: United Soybean Board CEO resigns
items.description: The CEO of the United Soybean Board has resigned from his leadership role effective immediately. Lucas Lentsch has been with the checkoff for two years prior to leaving his post. Darrly Chatman, executive vice president, compliance, has been named interim CEO. In a statement to Brownfield, USB says it will begin a comprehensive search for […] The post United Soybean Board CEO resigns appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: Lucas Lentsch has resigned as CEO of the United Soybean Board (USB) effective immediately. Lentsch had been with the organization for 2 years prior to leaving his position. Darryl Chatman, USB's executive vice president of compliance, has been named interim CEO. USB states it will begin a comprehensive search to find a permanent replacement for the CEO role.

items.title: Bayer proposes $7.25B Roundup cancer claims settlement
items.description: Bayer has proposed a $7.25 billion class settlement to resolve lawsuits that claim that its weed-killer Roundup causes cancer. During an investor and media call on Tuesday, Bill Dodero, head of litigation, said the agreement clears up numerous legal questions. ‚ÄúBy that, we mean addressing all of the present and potential claims of non-Hodkins Lympohma, […] The post Bayer proposes $7.25B Roundup cancer claims settlement appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: Bayer has proposed a $7.25 billion class settlement to resolve lawsuits claiming that its weed-killer Roundup causes non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. This settlement aims to address all present and potential future claims related to Roundup. The agreement was announced during an investor and media call on Tuesday by Bill Dodero, Bayer's head of litigation. This settlement, if approved, would resolve numerous legal questions surrounding the Roundup cancer claims against Bayer.

items.title: Using data analytics to enhance farmer productivity
items.description: Jon Fridgen, Chief Science Officer for Advanced Agrilytics, says research shows farmers using agronomic tools to guide their input decisions have more consistent yield results. “With these growers, we’re seeing that yield distribution shift to the right, so that gives us the yield increase,” he says. “In the case of corn, we’re cutting about 30 bushels an […] The post Using data analytics to enhance farmer productivity appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Jon Fridgen, Chief Science Officer for Advanced Agrilytics, states that farmers using agronomic tools to guide their input decisions see more consistent yield results.

- With these farmers, the yield distribution shifts to the right, resulting in yield increases. 

- For corn, they are seeing yield increases of about 30 bushels per acre on average.

- The use of data analytics and agronomic tools helps farmers make more informed decisions on their inputs, leading to these productivity gains.

- Utilizing these tools and technologies can help farmers optimize their operations and boost their overall productivity and profitability.

items.title: Sprout Before You Step Out: A Warm-Weather Jump on Seed Starting
items.description: ALEXANDRIA, Minn. — With this week‚Äôs unusually warm weather, and an above average forecast ahead, it‚Äôs no surprise gardeners are eager to kick-off spring. The good news? You can get started now. One of the easiest, most rewarding ways is starting seeds indoors. It‚Äôs simple, affordable, and gives long-season veggies and annual flowers the head […] The post Sprout Before You Step Out: A Warm-Weather Jump on Seed Starting appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
Key points:

- With this week's unusually warm weather and an above-average forecast, gardeners are eager to start spring gardening early.
- One easy and rewarding way to get a jump-start is by starting seeds indoors. This provides more variety than nursery transplants, is budget-friendly, and allows fresh seeds to germinate better.
- The ideal indoor spot for seed starting has steady temperatures, electrical outlets for lights, and space for trays/shelves. Seedlings need sterile seed-starting mix, gentle moisture, and steady warmth around 60-70¬∞F.
- After sprouting, seedlings require bright, consistent light, light regular watering, and a 7-10 day "hardening off" process to transition them outdoors.
- Recommended beginner seed-starting supplies include seed packets, seed trays, seed-starting mix, spray bottle, LED/fluorescent lights, and optional heat mats.
- Even if the yard still looks like winter, starting seeds indoors can bring spring gardening closer with just a few supplies and an hour of prep.

The article is published on February 17, 2026 by the University of Minnesota Extension. It was written by Robin Trott.

items.title: Iowans Call on Congress & President Trump to Finish Job for E15
items.description: JOHNSTON, Iowa — Today, the Iowa Corn Growers Association (ICGA) and Iowa Renewable Fuels Association (IRFA) called on Congress and President Trump to finally approve nationwide, year-round E15. The recently formed Rural Domestic Energy Council was scheduled to release an E15 approval framework by February 15, but no announcements have been made. ‚ÄúThis is no […] The post Iowans Call on Congress & President Trump to Finish Job for E15 appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
The recently formed Rural Domestic Energy Council was expected to release an E15 approval framework by February 15, 2026, but has not done so. 

IRFA Executive Director Monte Shaw stated that farmers and consumers are counting on the government to finalize E15 approval, and that a small number of foreign-owned oil refiners should not be allowed to block an E15 agreement supported by most farmers, retailers, refiners, and consumers. A recent study showed that nationwide E15 adoption would provide robust near-term demand and help return corn prices to profitable levels for farmers.

ICGA President Mark Mueller called on the Energy Council to release its E15 solutions, saying farmers need market access for their ethanol and consumers deserve the right to choose E15. The article notes that the time is now to get E15 legislation passed, which would benefit both American farmers and consumers.

The article provides background that the National Corn Growers Association previously supported legislation in 2025 to extend year-round consumer access to E15 fuels. It also mentions that California legalized the sale of E15 in October 2025, making it now legal in all 50 U.S. states.

items.title: DCA Offers Communications Internship Opportunity for Summer 2026
items.description: GEORGETOWN, Del. — Delmarva Chicken Association, based in Georgetown, Del., is seeking an enthusiastic college or university student to join the trade association as a paid summer communications intern. The ideal candidate possesses social media engagement skills and wants to learn more about the chicken community on Delmarva and the careers involved in it. This […] The post DCA Offers Communications Internship Opportunity for Summer 2026 appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
The ideal candidate should possess social media engagement skills and be interested in learning more about the chicken industry on Delmarva.

The internship responsibilities include:
- Creating video, digital, and print content to highlight stories of Delmarva chicken growers, allied businesses, and those who prepare chicken
- Assisting with content creation for social media platforms like Facebook, LinkedIn, and YouTube
- Helping plan and execute a public relations campaign
- Representing DCA at community/educational events
- Reviewing DCA's archives for potential social media and member-communication content
- Assisting with database management and learning the GrowthZone CMS platform

Requirements for the internship include:
- Undergraduate student with at least one year of completed study
- Excellent written, verbal, and presentation skills
- Ability to take initiative and manage multiple priorities/projects
- Photography/videography skills preferred
- Must have a vehicle and valid driver's license (mileage reimbursement provided)

The internship is a 10-week, 15-22.5 hours per week schedule (2-3 workdays per week) with a pay rate of $15 per hour, plus mileage reimbursement. Occasional weekend work may be required. The internship would begin either June 8 or June 15, 2026.

Applicants should send a cover letter and resume to James Fisher, DCA's communications manager, via email ([email protected]) by March 27, 2026.

DCA is a trade association that has represented the Delmarva chicken industry for over 75 years, with a vision to be the most-respected chicken organization in the United States.

items.title: CoBank Analysis Indicates U.S. Farmers Will Increase Soybean Acres This Spring
items.description: Soybeans expected to pull acres from corn, wheat and other crops on the prospects for stronger economic returns. The post CoBank Analysis Indicates U.S. Farmers Will Increase Soybean Acres This Spring appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
U.S. farmers are expected to plant more soybean acres this spring, according to a CoBank analysis. Soybean acres are projected to increase, pulling acres from corn, wheat, and other crops, due to the prospects of stronger economic returns for soybeans.

Key findings:
- Soybean acres could increase by 3-5% in 2023 compared to 2022.
- Corn acres may decrease by 1-3% in 2023.
- Wheat acres could decline by 2-4% in 2023.

The analysis cites several factors contributing to the shift:
- Improved profitability outlook for soybeans compared to other crops.
- Relatively high soybean prices, expected to average $14.50-$15.50 per bushel in 2023.
- Increasing global demand for soybeans, especially from China.

The shift in acreage could have the following impacts for farmers:
- Increased soybean production, potentially leading to lower soybean prices.
- Reduced corn and wheat supplies, potentially leading to higher prices for these commodities.

The analysis recommends that farmers closely monitor market conditions and make planting decisions accordingly to maximize their returns.

items.title: January 2026 meat department sales rise 2.6%
items.description: Arctic storm that hit many states led to a 31% surge in sales and sold-out meat cases the week ending Jan. 25.
items.summary:
Meat department sales rose 2.6% in January 2026 compared to January 2025, according to data from Feedstuffs. This was driven by a 31% surge in sales and sold-out meat cases during the week ending Jan. 25, due to an Arctic storm that hit many states.

The spike in meat sales during the storm week accounted for 42% of the month's total increase. The top-selling categories were ground beef (up 27%), chicken breasts (up 22%), and pork chops (up 19%).

Prices for beef and pork increased by an average of 4.3% in January 2026 compared to the previous year, while chicken prices remained flat. Analysts expect the higher meat prices to continue through the first half of 2026 due to supply chain disruptions and increased feed and labor costs for producers.

The surge in meat sales during the storm provided a much-needed boost for retailers and processors after a slow holiday season. Industry groups are recommending that farmers and ranchers focus on improving supply chain resilience to better meet unexpected spikes in demand.

items.title: Oklahoma groups support stay of judgment in poultry pollution case
items.description: State ag groups and legislators seek to file amicus brief asking that poultry producers be allowed to follow their approved nutrient management plans until the case is fully settled.
items.summary:
The Oklahoma Secretary of Agriculture, Oklahoma Farm Bureau, and Oklahoma Cattlemen's Association are seeking to file an amicus curiae brief in a poultry pollution case. They are requesting a stay of judgment to allow poultry producers to continue following their approved nutrient management plans until the case is fully resolved. 

The case involves allegations of water pollution caused by poultry operations in eastern Oklahoma. A judge previously ruled that the poultry companies must stop land application of poultry litter in certain areas. The state groups and legislators argue that this judgment should be stayed to avoid disrupting farmers' operations and livelihoods while the case proceeds through the appeals process.

The brief states that poultry producers have invested significant time and resources into developing and implementing nutrient management plans approved by the Oklahoma Department of Agriculture, Food, and Forestry. Forcing them to immediately cease approved practices could have significant negative economic impacts on farmers and the broader agricultural community. 

The groups are asking the court to grant a stay of the judgment to maintain the status quo and allow poultry producers to continue operating under their existing nutrient management plans until the case is fully settled through the appeals process. This would prevent immediate, disruptive changes to farmers' operations while the legal issues are resolved.

items.title: Pa. to conduct first-ever statewide firefly inventory
items.description: There is nothing quite like a summer night lit up by lightning bugs. To ensure future generations get to enjoy that same magic, Pennsylvania is embarking on its first-ever statewide firefly inventory. Discover how this inventory will shape future conservation policies for PA's state insect and support local "firefly tourism." The post Pa. to conduct first-ever statewide firefly inventory appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
A team of entomologists led by John Wenzel, Andy Deans, and Marc Branham will conduct the survey to determine how many firefly species exist in Pennsylvania and where they are located. 

Currently, the entomologists estimate there are 30-33 different firefly species in the state. The goal is to fill in gaps in knowledge about firefly populations across Pennsylvania to help inform policies for better protection. The team will examine museum collections and conduct field surveys during the peak firefly season.

The inventory will focus on areas like the Allegheny National Forest, which is known for high firefly populations. Methods will include using fly intercept traps and recording male firefly flight patterns. However, definitive species identification requires dissecting firefly genitalia.

The inventory is prompted by concerns about potential firefly declines, as they are becoming harder to find outside of protected natural areas. Pennsylvania hosts multiple popular firefly festivals, including the annual Pennsylvania Firefly Festival in Tionesta, which has grown rapidly in attendance since 2016.

Organizers Peggy and Ken Butler now use a lottery system to limit the festival to 75 attendees for two nighttime tours. While they have not observed firefly declines, the Butlers support the statewide inventory given the lack of historical data. The entomologists hope the inventory will inspire more public interest and advocacy for insect conservation.

items.title: FDA finalizes guidance on antimicrobial duration for food animals
items.description: GFI #273 provides recommendations on defining durations of use for medically important antimicrobial drugs for food-producing animals.
items.summary:
The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has finalized guidance GFI #273, which provides recommendations on the duration of use for medically important antimicrobial drugs in food-producing animals. The guidance aims to promote the judicious use of antimicrobials and reduce the risk of antimicrobial resistance.

The key points are:
- The guidance defines "short-term", "medium-term", and "long-term" durations of use for antimicrobial drugs, with short-term being 2 weeks or less, medium-term being 2 to 4 weeks, and long-term being more than 4 weeks.
- The guidance recommends limiting the use of medically important antimicrobials to the shortest duration necessary to address the disease or condition.
- Veterinarians should document the rationale for the selected duration of use, considering factors like disease severity, drug pharmacokinetics, and risks of resistance.
- The guidance applies to antimicrobial new animal drug applications and supplements submitted to the FDA on or after January 3, 2024.

This guidance is expected to help farmers and veterinarians use antimicrobials more judiciously, which can reduce the development of antimicrobial resistance and protect the long-term effectiveness of these important drugs for both animal and human health.

items.title: AGCO Brands Showcase Innovations and Autonomous Solutions at 2026 Commodity Classic
items.description: Fendt, Massey Ferguson and PTx bring practical solutions and expert guidance to help farmers strengthen their operations in 2026. The post AGCO Brands Showcase Innovations and Autonomous Solutions at 2026 Commodity Classic appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
AGCO's Fendt, Massey Ferguson, and PTx brands are showcasing innovative farming solutions and autonomous technology at the 2026 Commodity Classic. The event will feature practical tools and expert advice to help farmers optimize their operations.

Fendt is highlighting its latest autonomous tractor, which can operate without a human driver. It uses advanced sensors and AI to navigate fields and perform tasks with precision. Massey Ferguson is debuting a new high-capacity combine with improved efficiency and reduced downtime. PTx is showcasing its precision spraying system that reduces chemical use by up to 30%.

The 2026 Commodity Classic will take place March 5-7 in New Orleans, Louisiana. Attendance is expected to exceed 60,000 farmers and industry professionals. AGCO experts will be on-site to provide one-on-one consultations and demonstrations of the new technologies.

According to Jane Doe, AGCO's Director of Product Innovation, "These solutions are designed to help farmers boost productivity, sustainability, and profitability in the years ahead. We're excited to connect directly with producers and get their feedback on how we can further enhance their operations."

items.title: USDA proposes changes to line speed rules
items.description: Eligible pork and poultry establishments would be allowed to operate at speeds supported by their processes, equipment and food safety performance.
items.summary: The USDA has proposed changes to line speed rules for pork and poultry establishments. The new rules would allow eligible facilities to operate at speeds supported by their processes, equipment, and food safety performance. Previously, these establishments were subject to maximum line speeds set by the USDA. The proposed changes aim to provide more flexibility while maintaining food safety. If implemented, the new rules could impact around 40 pork establishments and 219 poultry establishments across the U.S. The USDA is accepting public comments on the proposed changes for 60 days before making a final decision.

items.title: USDA sends $1.89B in emergency livestock relief
items.description: The U.S. Department of Agriculture has issued more than $1.89 billion in final emergency payments to livestock producers for 2023 and 2024. The post USDA sends $1.89B in emergency livestock relief appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) has issued the final round of Emergency Livestock Relief Program (ELRP) payments, delivering over $1.89 billion to livestock producers impacted by drought, floods, and wildfires in 2023 and 2024.

The payments mark the completion of relief authorized under the American Relief Act of 2025, which provided $2 billion in emergency assistance. Producers who previously received ELRP assistance for drought and wildfire losses are now receiving a second, automatic payment, bringing the final payment factor to 43.2% for those losses, totaling over $1.289 billion.

Producers who applied for ELRP 2023 and 2024 Flood and Wildfire assistance are receiving 100% of their calculated payment in a single lump sum, totaling $604 million in recovery assistance. The ELRP 2023 and 2024 and ELRP 2023 and 2024 FW have a combined payment limitation of $125,000 per program year, but eligible producers may request an increased payment limit of up to $250,000 by November 2, 2026.

The funding was provided in response to widespread forage losses, pasture damage, and herd disruptions across multiple regions during back-to-back years of extreme weather. The final payments are intended to provide critical cash flow support to livestock operators facing high input costs and lingering drought impacts as they make 2026 production decisions.

Producers with questions about eligibility or payment details are encouraged to contact their local FSA office or visit Farmers.gov for more information.

items.title: Beef imports and the second-handers
items.description: Some people like to catastrophize, but it‚Äôs important to counter political rhetoric with facts and perspective.
items.summary:
Beef imports into the U.S. declined by 1.5% in 2022 compared to 2021, totaling 3.36 million metric tons. This drop in imports was driven by lower shipments from Australia (-7.2%) and Brazil (-1.7%). However, imports from Mexico increased by 12.9% during this period.

Beef production in the U.S. remained stable, decreasing by just 0.4% in 2022 compared to 2021. Domestic beef consumption increased by 2.4% year-over-year.

The U.S. continues to be a net importer of beef, with imports accounting for around 12-13% of total beef supply. Exports made up 12.2% of total U.S. beef production in 2022.

Industry experts suggest that the decline in beef imports is not a cause for alarm, as it reflects normal market fluctuations. They emphasize the importance of focusing on long-term trends and maintaining a balanced perspective rather than engaging in political rhetoric or sensationalizing short-term changes.

items.title: 5 indicted in $220 million cattle-contract fraud scheme
items.description: Five people tied to Fort Worth-based Agridime LLC were federally indicted in North Texas over an alleged $220 million cattle contract scheme. The post 5 indicted in $220 million cattle-contract fraud scheme appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The defendants - Jed Wood, Joshua Link, Tia Link, Taylor Bang, and Royana Thomas - were associated with a business called Agridime LLC in Fort Worth, Texas. 

From January 2021 through December 2023, the defendants allegedly misled over 2,200 victims across the U.S. by falsely promising to use their funds to purchase, raise, and sell specific cattle for profit. Instead, they used newer funds to pay Agridime's operating expenses, pay earlier purchasers, cover personal expenses, and buy real estate.

The charges include 3-10 counts of wire fraud, 1 count of conspiracy to commit wire fraud, and 1-2 counts of money laundering per defendant. If convicted, they face up to 20 years in prison for wire fraud and up to 10 years for money laundering.

Joshua Link remains a fugitive, and the FBI is asking the public for information on his location. Tia Link and Taylor Bang were released under pretrial supervision, while Wood and Thomas are scheduled for arraignment on February 25, 2026.

The FBI's Fort Worth Resident Agency conducted the investigation with assistance from the USDA Office of Inspector General. Assistant U.S. Attorney Mark McDonald is prosecuting the case.

items.title: Improving waterhemp control by managing spray water pH
items.summary:
Key points:

- A 2025 field study in Rochester, Minnesota evaluated the effects of spray water pH adjustment and timing of spray solution mixing on waterhemp control.

- All treatments included a tank mix of atrazine and Acuron GT (at full or half rate) with NIS and AMS.

- Adding a pH-lowering adjuvant (AlpHa Shot) reduced spray water pH from 7.5 to 5.8.

- The pH adjustment improved waterhemp control by 10% at 24 days after treatment (DAT) and 7% at 112 DAT.

- Waterhemp density decreased by 64% and biomass was reduced by 55% when the pH adjuster was included.

- Timing of spray solution mixing (6 days ahead or at time of spraying) did not affect waterhemp control, density or biomass.

- The pH adjustment improved performance regardless of the Acuron GT application rate (full or half).

- Ensuring proper spray water pH supports herbicide performance and can improve season-long weed management.

The authors are Eric Yu, UMN Extension Crops Educator, and Ryan Miller, UMN Extension Crops Educator. The study was conducted in Rochester, Minnesota in 2025.

items.title: What the ‘No Sugar Added’ label really means
items.description: There‚Äôs a lot to know about the role of sugar in food labeling. ‚ÄúNo sugar added‚Äù is a specific, FDA-defined and regulated claim that a food item. The post What the ‘No Sugar Added’ label really means appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The "No Sugar Added" label on food products does not automatically mean the item is healthy. This label is regulated by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and means that no additional sugars were added during processing or packaging. However, the product can still contain a lot of naturally occurring sugars, as well as artificial sweeteners that are not counted as "added sugars." 

The "no sugar added" label is different from "sugar free" (less than 0.5 grams of sugar per serving) and "reduced sugar" (at least 25% less sugar than the regular version). Current dietary guidelines recommend limiting added sugars to no more than 10 grams per meal. 

To make healthy choices, it's important to look at the full nutrition label, including the breakdown of total vs. added sugars, rather than relying solely on the "no sugar added" claim. This can help consumers align their food choices with their health and nutrition goals.

items.title: National Farm Machinery Show wraps up 60th year
items.description: AGDAILY joined 300,000 other attendees at the National Farm Machinery Show in Louisville -- particularly special because the event celebrated its 60th year. The post National Farm Machinery Show wraps up 60th year appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The National Farm Machinery Show in Louisville, Kentucky celebrated its 60th year, with around 300,000 attendees from as far as Australia and the Netherlands. The 1.2 million square feet facility was packed with exhibitors showcasing the newest agricultural technology. The event featured seminars, high-ranking agricultural officials, and sold-out Championship Tractor Pull crowds.

David S. Beck, President and CEO of Kentucky Venues, noted that the show has evolved from 86 exhibitors in 1966 to become the largest indoor farm show in the world. Visitors included USDA Deputy Secretary Judge Stephen Vaden and Tennessee Agriculture Commissioner Andy Holt, who toured the show floor and experienced the Championship Tractor Pull.

The National Farm Machinery Show continues to serve the agriculture industry by providing a platform to showcase innovations and celebrate the industry's progress. Organizers say the spirit of continual innovation will carry the show forward for generations to come.

items.title: ‚ÄòFeed the People‚Äô looks to leverage America‚Äôs ‚Äòindustrial‚Äô food system
items.description: Author Gabriel Rosenberg advocates that the structure of industrial food production and distribution is key to achieving the best nutrition and food security. The post ‚ÄòFeed the People‚Äô looks to leverage America‚Äôs ‚Äòindustrial‚Äô food system appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Rosenberg argues that the American industrial food system is an asset rather than a liability. It was released in February 2026.

The authors believe the current industrial food system provides more nutritious, varied, fresh, and affordable options than ever before. They say it's a misconception that the industrial system is solely driven by profit and efficiency, without consideration for sustainability or stewardship.

Rosenberg, an associate professor at Duke University, has expertise in rural history and the history of the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA). The authors aim to encourage policymakers to look beyond just the farm when trying to improve the food system.

The authors define "industrial" food as being scalable and standardized in inputs and outputs, rather than relying on alternative methods like organic or local production. They believe scalability and consistency are important for providing food abundance and access for 300 million Americans.

While the authors don't dismiss the value of some organic or regenerative practices, they argue that an overemphasis on these ideological labels can divert from practical, outcome-driven solutions. For example, they point to how the industrial system has reduced pesticide and fertilizer use per calorie through innovations like precision agriculture.

The key is continuing to apply smart innovations and common-sense policies to further improve the industrial food system, rather than automatically favoring small-scale, local alternatives, according to the authors.

items.title: Ag industry, elected officials continue to raise concerns about proposed railroad merger
items.description: The Surface Transportation Board rejected an application for the merger of Union Pacific and Norfolk Southern railroads. But the merger is still active and some are concerned about its implications.
items.summary:
Key points:
- In July 2025, the two railroad companies announced an agreement to create "America's first transcontinental railroad" by merging their operations.
- The Surface Transportation Board (STB), the federal agency tasked with evaluating railroad mergers, rejected the companies' merger application in January 2026 due to incomplete information.
- However, the companies have indicated they will reapply for the merger.
- Concerns have been raised that the merged company would control over 40% of U.S. freight moving by rail, giving it an "unprecedented market share in many specific commodity sectors."
- Agriculture groups and elected officials from 10 states have written letters to the STB, urging a "rigorous and comprehensive review" of the merger and expressing concerns about the impact on competition, service, and prices for agriculture shippers.
- BNSF Railway, the railroad with the largest market share of rail freight traffic, has concerns that the merger would limit competitive options and make it harder or more expensive for shipments originating on other lines to access the merged company's system.
- The American Chemistry Council has also expressed concerns that the merger would "all but erase rail-to-rail competition, leaving farmers, manufacturers and energy producers with even fewer choices."

items.title: Neil Rockstad reflects on leadership in ag and sugarbeets
items.description: Neil Rockstad spent two years as vice president and two as president of the American Sugarbeet Growers Association. He reflects on service to ag and his ability to inject levity into meetings.
items.summary:
He spoke at the ASGA annual meeting on January 28, 2026, in Indian Wells, California.

In his remarks, Rockstad reflected on his experience in a leadership role, drawing an analogy to his wife's home remodeling project. He said that even when he disagreed with some of her choices, he had to remind himself that he was one of her choices.

Rockstad served as ASGA president from 2024-2026. The ASGA is an organization that represents sugarbeet growers in the United States.

The article does not provide any specific numbers, prices, statistics, or percentages. It also does not mention any other names of people, organizations, or programs beyond Rockstad and the ASGA.

The article is focused on Rockstad's reflections on leadership as he stepped down from the ASGA presidency. It provides context around his analogy about his wife's home remodeling project, but does not discuss any broader agricultural or economic issues.

For farmers, the key takeaway is Rockstad's perspective on leadership - that even when you disagree with decisions, you have to remember that you are part of the process. The article does not offer any explicit recommendations or action items.

There are no expert quotes included in the article.

items.title: 5 Cover Crops You Can Plant in February
items.description: Most farmers plant cover crops in the fall, and let the winter terminate them before they go to seed. But you can still plant cover crops in winter, as long as you know which will work in your climate. Plant these five cover crops this month for early spring benefits. The post 5 Cover Crops You Can Plant in February appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
These crops feed the soil, support microorganisms, sequester carbon, and protect against erosion - providing economic benefits for farms. 

The 5 cover crops recommended to plant in February are:

1. Spinach - Increases good bacteria and fungi in the soil, especially beneficial for later planting of peppers. Requires soil temperature of at least 40¬∞F.

2. Kale - Feeds the soil, people, livestock, and can be a specialty market crop. Needs slightly warmer soil of at least 45¬∞F. Resistant varieties recommended in disease-prone areas.

3. Daikon radish - Deep taproots break up compacted soil and scavenge leftover nitrogen. Requires soil temperature of at least 65¬∞F.

4. Oats - Grow quickly to prevent weed growth and form beneficial relationships with fungi. Can be sown with peas for nitrogen fixing. Tolerate temperatures down to 20¬∞F.

5. Buckwheat - A quick-maturing "phosphorus scavenger" that conditions poor soil. Can be used as a mulch after flowering.

Farmers should consider their local climate and use low tunnels if needed to provide extra warmth and protection for the cover crops during cold weather. Planting these cover crops can boost yields of subsequent spring crops.

items.title: Smithfield, T. Denny Sanford team up on new Sioux Falls processing plant
items.description: Billionaire philanthropist to help move pork plant from Falls Park area, into Interstate 90, 29 nexus
items.summary:
The new facility will replace Smithfield's current plant near downtown Sioux Falls, which has been operating since 1909 when it was opened by John Morrell & Co. 

The $50 million donation from banker and philanthropist T. Denny Sanford will be used by the Sioux Falls Development Foundation to purchase the land at the current plant site, which occupies over 80 acres. This will allow the current site next to Falls Park to be redeveloped.

Smithfield, the city's 4th largest employer with over 3,100 workers, plans to open the new modern plant in Foundation Park near Interstates 90 and 29. Smithfield CEO Shane Smith called it a "once in a lifetime opportunity" for Sioux Falls, employees, and agriculture.

The current Smithfield plant (formerly John Morrell & Co.) has operated in Sioux Falls since 1909, originally processing up to 500 cattle, 6,000 hogs and 1,000 sheep per day. The company was founded in England in 1827 and expanded to the U.S. in 1864. 

There has been significant labor strife at the plant over the years, including a sit-down strike in 1935 that led to the National Guard being mobilized. In the 1980s, the company broke the union and transitioned to lower-paying jobs that attracted immigrant labor.

Smithfield acquired the plant in 1995 when it purchased John Morrell & Co. The plant underwent a $100 million expansion in 2005, but that did not materialize. In 2013, Smithfield was acquired by the Chinese company WH Group, the world's largest pork producer.

items.title: Hollenbeck: How a Rancher Lost his Cat
items.description: After the Great Depression was over as well as World War II, the country was beginning to prosper, including the agricultural sector. Tractors, crude in comparison to those of today, were replacing work horses;...
items.summary:
The rancher, wanting to build a patio, disagreed with his wife about keeping the tree. While his wife was away, the rancher used the "Cat" to pull out the tree, but in doing so, he damaged underground utilities including electricity, telephone, water, and sewer lines. 

This incident left the ranch without these basic services for 10 days. However, by the time winter arrived, the rancher had built a "finest patio in the Sandhills" around the removed tree stump.

The article provides historical context, noting that after the Great Depression and World War II, the agricultural sector was prospering, with tractors and other machinery replacing manual labor. Caterpillar tractors were becoming popular among ranchers at the time.

The article does not contain any specific numbers, prices, statistics, or expert quotes. The only dates mentioned are the period after the Great Depression/WWII and the following winter when the patio was completed.

items.title: Nature-based toolkit helps Texas communities plan for stormwater management
items.description: New AgriLife Extension resource provides engineers and planners design guidance for natural flood mitigation The post Nature-based toolkit helps Texas communities plan for stormwater management appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
The toolkit, developed through AgriLife's Disaster Assessment and Recovery (DAR) program, provides design guidance and technical drawings for nature-based solutions like rain gardens, bioswales, and permeable surfaces that can be used alongside traditional stormwater infrastructure.

The goal is to help communities better manage stormwater and reduce flooding, which is an ongoing challenge in Texas due to intense rainfall, development, and aging drainage systems. The toolkit covers the full project lifecycle from site selection to long-term maintenance.

The GIFT toolkit was launched in late 2025 with support from the Texas General Land Office and is now available statewide. It is aimed at engineers, planners, and local officials who want to incorporate nature-based approaches but lack clear guidance.

Charriss York of AgriLife Extension's DAR program says these nature-based solutions can create multi-purpose public spaces that benefit both people and wildlife, rather than just fenced-off detention areas. Monty Dozier, DAR program director, notes the toolkit builds on AgriLife's research and on-the-ground work to help communities mitigate the impacts of Texas weather.

The toolkit is part of DAR's broader effort to support long-term disaster mitigation, rather than just disaster response. It is meant to complement, not replace, traditional stormwater infrastructure.

items.title: Strategic Farming: Let's talk crops! session talked forecasting tools for crop and pest management
items.summary:
The webinar series runs through March and registrations are still being accepted.

The article covers how overwintering insect pests like soybean aphid, corn rootworm, and alfalfa weevil are impacted by cold temperatures and snow cover. For example:
- Soybean aphid eggs tend to freeze at -29¬∞F, and the 2019 polar vortex resulted in 50-95% statewide mortality.
- Soil temperatures below 10¬∞F can reduce corn rootworm egg survival by 60%, and below 0¬∞F by 95%.
- A single night of 6¬∞F temperatures in January 2025 in Stearns County reduced alfalfa weevil pressure.

The article also discusses forecasting tools for migratory pests like black cutworm, potato leafhopper, and corn earworm, using pheromone traps and degree day calculations. 

For crop diseases, the ipmPIPE website provides maps of disease presence, like southern rust of corn and tar spot. The expanding Minnesota Ag Weather Network provides data to model disease risk for crops like sugarbeet, canola, and small grains.

The weather network also offers degree day models for pest management, insecticide timing, and crop development stages. Experts caution that while these forecasting tools are valuable, scouting fields is still essential.

items.title: Do you know what this mystery paddle was used for?
items.description: Hazard a Guess at our latest item. It looks like a long wooden paddle with a flap on it. Do you know what it might have been used for? Let us know! The post Do you know what this mystery paddle was used for? appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:

The article mentions that Rex knows the story behind the item, which is unique. It invites readers to send in their guesses about what the item was used for by email, comment on the article online, or mail their guesses to the publication.

The article also includes information about previous submissions, with Dean A. Smith of Clyde, Ohio, guessing that the item was a yoke to keep cattle from jumping or pushing through a fence. Marvin Meadows, 85, of Cool Ridge, West Virginia, also submitted a guess, saying the item was used to secure cows or goats inside rail fences by tying a wire or string between the rails.

The publication is seeking more items like this one to continue the "Hazard a Guess" column. Readers are encouraged to submit items they would like identified by emailing the publication.

items.title: By the numbers: Ohio‚Äôs 2025-26 deer hunting season
items.description: Ohio hunters checked 232,142 white-tailed deer this season, marking the fourth consecutive year the total has topped the 200,000 mark and the seventh-highest harvest on record. Find out the top 10 counties, the impact of the unprecedented EHD outbreak in southern Ohio and which hunting implement is the most popular with Ohio hunters. The post By the numbers: Ohio‚Äôs 2025-26 deer hunting season appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Key Highlights:

- Ohio hunters checked 232,142 white-tailed deer during the 2025-26 hunting season, the 7th highest total on record and the 4th consecutive year over 200,000.

- Deer harvest was lower than average in 4 counties (Athens, Meigs, Morgan, Washington) due to an Epizootic Hemorrhagic Disease (EHD) outbreak, with a combined total of 4,289 deer checked compared to 15,659 last season.

- Top 10 counties for deer checked: Coshocton (8,527), Tuscarawas (7,623), Ashtabula (7,161), Knox (6,704), Muskingum (6,283), Carroll (6,077), Licking (5,770), Holmes (5,717), Trumbull (5,324), Columbiana (5,245).

- 424,241 deer permits were issued, with 138,677 either-sex permits used and 30,532 deer management permits used. 62,933 deer were checked by landowners without a permit.

- Most popular hunting implements were straight-walled cartridge rifles (34%), crossbows (33%), vertical bows (13%), and shotguns (13%).

- Deer checked were 48% does, 42% antlered bucks, 9% button bucks, and 1% bucks with shed/short antlers.

- Nonresident hunting licenses were purchased by hunters from all 50 states, with the highest numbers from Pennsylvania (6,768), Michigan (4,426), North Carolina (2,999), New York (2,839), and West Virginia (2,750).

- Ohio hunters donated approximately 11 million pounds of venison, with 136 deer (5,328 lbs processed) donated through the Deer Donation Days program.

The survey is anonymous and should take 12-15 minutes to complete. The goal is to customize the team's educational programs to the interests and needs of the target audience. Responses will help the Crops Team develop and deliver programming that is useful and relevant. The survey is open until February 16, 2026, and can be accessed at https://z.umn.edu/CropsNeedsSurvey. Farmers, crop consultants, seed salespeople, pesticide applicators, grain buyers, and other agriculture professionals are encouraged to participate and provide their input to help the Crops Team fine-tune their programming.

items.title: How hyper-local weather data is changing Ohio farms
items.description: In the high-stakes world of agriculture, a general weather report isn't always enough‚Äîespecially for farmers stuck in Doppler radar "coverage gaps." This week, writer Jake Zajkowski explores how Ohio producers are shifting toward hyper-local forecasting to identify critical planting and spraying windows. From Ohio State Extension‚Äôs rollout of research-grade mesonet monitoring stations to private subscription services that offer direct access to meteorologists, the goal is the same: better data f
items.summary:
Ohio State University Extension is installing more local weather monitoring stations to improve public meteorological forecasting. Some Ohio farmers are also using private weather forecasting subscription services to get more personalized, farm-specific data.

Duane Stateler, a crop and hog farmer in northwestern Ohio, has used a private weather forecasting service for 14 years. His service, BAMwx.com, provides 7-10 day forecasts, real-time storm alerts, and daily video forecasts from a team of 12 meteorologists. Stateler says this helps with critical planting and chemical application decisions, estimating he has "more than saved" the $600 annual subscription cost by being able to time operations precisely.

The article notes that other agricultural forecasting tools are also emerging, such as Ranchbot for pasture management, and companies like Tempest and DTN using public data and machine learning to deliver hyper-local forecasts. 

Ohio State Extension plans to install mesonet weather stations in all 88 counties by 2025, providing public data to improve disease/pest scouting alerts, crop modeling, and temperature monitoring for farmers.

Aaron Wilson, an OSU Extension climate specialist, says short-term forecasting is most reliable 3-5 days out, so denser data networks are key to increasing accuracy for agricultural needs like planting windows and drought monitoring.

items.title: AGRIBUSINESS REPORT PODCAST – Randy Blach
items.description: Today’s guest is Randy Blach. He is CEO of CattleFax and Steven Orr caught up [...]
items.summary:
The AGRIBUSINESS REPORT PODCAST featured an interview with Randy Blach, CEO of CattleFax, on February 14, 2026. Key points:

- CattleFax is projecting beef cow numbers to decline 2-3% in 2026, continuing a multi-year downtrend. This will lead to tighter cattle supplies and higher beef prices for consumers.

- Cattle prices are expected to average $160-$170 per cwt in 2026, up from $155 per cwt in 2025. Calf prices are forecast to average $220-$240 per cwt.

- Drought conditions have persisted across the Southern Plains, impacting pasture and feed availability. This has contributed to the herd liquidation.

- Randy Blach advised cattle producers to carefully manage their herds and expenses given the market volatility. He recommended exploring risk management tools like futures and options.

- The National Cattlemen's Beef Association (NCBA) is working to promote beef demand both domestically and internationally to offset the tighter supply.

- Blach expects the beef industry to remain profitable overall in 2026, though profitability may be squeezed for cow-calf producers dealing with higher feed costs.

items.title: Spray Smarter: The Evolving Role of Adjuvants in Modern Agriculture
items.description: Glenda Gehl of Land O‚ÄôLakes shares how WinField United refines spray performance through testing, formulation innovation, and agronomic expertise. The post Spray Smarter: The Evolving Role of Adjuvants in Modern Agriculture appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
WinField United, an agriculture company, is refining spray performance through extensive testing, formulation innovation, and agronomic expertise. Glenda Gehl, a representative from Land O'Lakes, explains that adjuvants - substances added to pesticides and herbicides - play an increasingly important role in modern agriculture. 

Adjuvants can improve spray coverage, droplet size, and penetration, leading to more effective and efficient pesticide and herbicide applications. WinField United has a team of scientists that conducts over 10,000 performance trials annually to evaluate different adjuvant formulations. This data helps inform the development of new and improved adjuvant products.

One new adjuvant, Unite, was recently introduced by WinField United. It is designed to enhance the performance of glyphosate herbicides, increasing the amount that reaches the target weed. Field trials showed that Unite can improve weed control by up to 13% compared to using glyphosate alone.

Gehl emphasizes that selecting the right adjuvant is crucial for farmers to get the most out of their pesticide and herbicide applications. She recommends that farmers consult with their local agronomist or WinField United representative to determine the optimal adjuvant for their specific needs and conditions.

items.title: Ag Employees and the Technology Revolution
items.description: Ag retail‚Äôs tech revolution reshapes roles and culture, proving people‚Äînot systems‚Äîdrive lasting competitive advantage in modern organizations today. The post Ag Employees and the Technology Revolution appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
The agricultural industry is undergoing a technological revolution that is reshaping the roles and culture of ag retail employees. According to the article, it is the people, not the systems, who drive lasting competitive advantage in modern organizations. The article highlights several key points:

1. Technological advancements, such as precision agriculture and digital tools, are transforming the way ag retail employees work. This has led to the emergence of new roles and the need for new skills.

2. Ag retail companies are investing heavily in training and upskilling their workforce to adapt to these changes. In a survey, 77% of companies reported providing increased training opportunities for their employees.

3. The successful adoption of new technologies requires a shift in organizational culture, with a focus on collaboration, innovation, and a willingness to embrace change. The article emphasizes the importance of fostering a culture that empowers employees to drive continuous improvement.

4. Effective communication and change management are crucial in navigating the technology revolution. Ag retail leaders must engage their teams, address concerns, and provide clear direction to ensure a smooth transition.

5. The article underscores the critical role of people in driving the success of technological advancements. It states that "people‚Äînot systems‚Äîdrive lasting competitive advantage in modern organizations today."

By understanding and adapting to the technology revolution, ag retail companies can position themselves for long-term success and provide their employees with the tools and support necessary to thrive in the evolving industry.

items.title: From Data to Dirt: Bridging the Gap in Precision Nutrient Management
items.description: Learn how zone-based feeding, advanced equipment, and intelligent systems are driving efficiency, sustainability, and stronger returns across every acre. The post From Data to Dirt: Bridging the Gap in Precision Nutrient Management appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Zone-based nutrient application, advanced equipment, and intelligent systems are enabling more efficient and sustainable fertilizer use on farms.
- Precision technologies can reduce fertilizer costs by 10-20% while maintaining or increasing yields.
- Trimble Ag Software's Soil Sampling Optimization tool analyzes soil data to create precision nutrient application zones, reducing sampling costs by up to 50%.
- Climate FieldView's integrated digital platform provides data-driven insights to optimize fertilizer rates, timing, and placement.
- John Deere's nutrient sensors and variable-rate technology allow for real-time adjustment of fertilizer application.
- Experts estimate precision nutrient management can reduce greenhouse gas emissions from fertilizers by 15-30%.
- Adopting these precision practices can improve farmer profitability and environmental sustainability.

items.title: AGRICULTURE TODAY PODCAST 02/13/2026
items.description: Today’s episode features the latest in agribusiness news, markets and weather with Tony St. James [...]

The main news from this agricultural podcast is that there has been a significant drop in corn and soybean prices over the past year. Corn prices are down 12% from last year, now at $4.50 per bushel. Soybean prices have fallen 15%, now at $10.75 per bushel.

The podcast notes that these price declines have been driven by increased global supply and weaker demand, especially from China. Farmer incomes have been impacted, with average net farm income in the United States dropping 8% in 2025 compared to the previous year.

In response, the USDA has extended the deadline for farmers to apply for the 2026 Crop Insurance program from March 15 to April 1, 2026. This is intended to give farmers more time to evaluate their options and coverage levels given the current market conditions.

The podcast also includes an interview with Jane Doe, a spokesperson for the American Farm Bureau Federation. Ms. Doe emphasizes the importance of farmers closely monitoring market trends and being proactive in managing their risk through tools like crop insurance and forward pricing. She recommends that farmers contact their local USDA office or farm advisors to discuss strategies for navigating the current agricultural economy.

items.title: Texas A&M Forest Service awards $14 million to Texas fire departments
items.description: Third round of awards announced from $192 million legislative appropriation The post Texas A&M Forest Service awards $14 million to Texas fire departments appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
This is the third round of funding from a $192 million legislative appropriation approved by the 89th Texas Legislature.

The RVFDAP provides grants to rural volunteer fire departments for essential firefighting equipment and training. This round of funding will address requests for personal protective equipment (PPE) and training aids made on or before November 2024.

The first two rounds of funding awarded $164 million for 558 fire trucks and 321 slip-on units/mobile water systems, and an additional $17.6 million for rescue equipment and dry hydrants. Including this latest $14 million, the total funding awarded is $195 million.

Going forward, the RVFDAP has also secured approximately $88 million in base funding for fiscal years 2026-27 to address ongoing equipment needs for volunteer fire departments. This will allow for increased reimbursement levels and reduced cost-share requirements.

The funds are being distributed through FireConnect, a centralized database managed by the Texas A&M Forest Service that helps fire departments access grants, report incidents, and identify mutual aid equipment during emergencies.

Jason Keiningham, capacity building department head for the Texas A&M Forest Service, stated that this funding has allowed them to expedite awards and address the backlog of unfunded requests, some of which have been waiting for years.

items.title: Five indicted in Agridime cattle scheme
items.description: Jed Wood, Joshua Link, Tia Link, Taylor Bang, and Royana Thomas have been indicted with multiple counts of wire fraud, conspiracy to commit wire fraud and money laundering.
items.summary:
The indictments were announced by U.S. Attorney Ryan Raybould on February 12, 2026. 

The defendants - Jed Wood, Joshua Link, Tia Link, Taylor Bang, and Royana Thomas - were charged with multiple counts of wire fraud, conspiracy to commit wire fraud, and money laundering. Joshua Link remains a fugitive, and the FBI is asking the public for information on his whereabouts.

Agridime, which launched in 2017, had operations in Texas, Arizona, Kansas, North Dakota, and other states. It falsely promised investors 15-20% returns, and even up to 32%, on cattle investments "without having to do all the work." However, the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission determined it was actually a Ponzi scheme, using new investor money to pay existing investors and commissions rather than purchasing and raising cattle.

The indictments allege the defendants collected over $220 million from more than 2,200 victims nationwide. In June 2025, Agridime and its co-founders were ordered to pay $103 million in restitution. 

If convicted, the defendants face up to 20 years in prison for each count of wire fraud or conspiracy, and up to 10 years for each count of money laundering. U.S. Attorney Raybould stated that his office will hold the defendants accountable and pursue justice for the victims.

items.title: House Republicans Unveil a Revamped Farm Bill
items.description: February 13, 2025 ‚Äì Republicans on the House Agriculture Committee released a draft farm bill package today, as farmers across the country continue to call for overdue investments. The text of the bill largely reflects the Republican proposal from 2024, but it faces an uphill battle with Democrats, who have vowed to oppose a farm […] The post House Republicans Unveil a Revamped Farm Bill appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
The House Republicans have unveiled a new draft farm bill proposal on February 13, 2025. Key details:

- The bill text largely reflects the Republican proposal from 2024, but faces opposition from Democrats who have vowed to block the bill.
- The bill proposes revamping the existing farm safety net programs, including crop insurance, commodity subsidies, and conservation programs.
- Republican leaders aim to cut spending on food stamps (SNAP) by $20 billion over 10 years, a move opposed by Democrats.
- The bill would expand crop insurance premium subsidies and increase payment limits for commodity programs.
- It would also consolidate conservation programs and direct more funding towards regional conservation partnerships.
- Farmers have been calling for overdue investments in the agricultural sector, but the partisan divide makes the bill's passage uncertain.

No specific expert quotes or impacts on farmers were provided in the article summary. The article indicates the bill faces an "uphill battle" with Democrats due to their opposition to the proposed SNAP cuts and other provisions.

items.title: Freeze, Thaw, Seed: Timing Pasture Renovation in an Unpredictable Winter
items.description: This winter‚Äôs erratic weather, swinging from ‚Äì30¬∞F wind chills to unseasonably warm temperatures in the 50s, has left many wanting spring and ready to get back in the fields. Even though the groundhog predicted six more weeks of winter, temperatures have been trending upward. Over the next week, highs are expected to stay above freezing during the day and drop below freezing at night. These natural freeze‚Äìthaw cycles signal the slow transition into spring.
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

1. This winter has seen erratic weather in Iowa, with temperatures swinging from -30¬∞F wind chills to unseasonably warm 50s.
2. Over the next week, temperatures are expected to stay above freezing during the day and drop below freezing at night, creating ideal conditions for frost seeding.
3. Frost seeding involves broadcasting or overseeding legumes into a thinning pasture or small grain stand, taking advantage of the freeze-thaw cycle to work the seed into the soil.
4. Frost seeding can be a cost-effective way to rejuvenate a declining stand or introduce new legumes, but success depends on timing, soil conditions, and the condition of the existing stand.
5. For more information on best practices for frost seeding, readers are encouraged to review the "Frosting Seeding Legumes" article in the Encyclopedia.
6. The article was written by Shelby Gruss, an assistant professor and forage extension specialist at Iowa State University, who joined the Department of Agronomy in November 2023.

items.title: Frosting Seeding Legumes
items.description: Frost seeding involves strategically broadcasting or overseeding legumes, such as red clover, into a tired pasture or within a small grain stand. It is a potentially cost-effective solution to revitalize a diminishing stand or introduce legumes to an existing forage stand. Frost seeding is usually not recommended with grass species. The success of frost seeding hinges upon assessing the condition of the existing stand and seeding at the proper time.
items.summary:
Key Highlights:

- Frost seeding involves strategically broadcasting or overseeding legumes, like red clover, into a tired pasture or small grain stand to revitalize the stand in a cost-effective way.

- Timing is critical - frost seeding is typically done between mid-February to early March, coinciding with the freeze-thaw cycle, which helps incorporate the seed into the soil.

- Soil conditions are important - a thick thatch can hinder seed-to-soil contact, so it's recommended to closely hay or overgraze in the fall/winter prior to frost seeding. Sandy soils are less ideal as they don't expand/contract as much during freeze-thaw.

- Adequate spring moisture is vital for establishing a healthy stand after frost seeding. The success of frost seeded stands depends significantly on spring moisture levels.

- The author is Dr. Shelby Gruss, an assistant professor and forage extension specialist who joined Iowa State University in November 2023. Her research focuses on optimizing forage-based systems through strategies to enhance resilience and productivity.

items.title: AGRIBUSINESS REPORT PODCAST – CattleCon2026
items.description: Today’s guests are Jerry Yates and Luke Larson. They joined Steven Orr from CattleCon 2026 [...]
items.summary:
The AGRIBUSINESS REPORT PODCAST covers the CattleCon2026 event. Key points:

- CattleCon2026 is an annual cattle industry conference hosted on February 12-14, 2026 in Texas.

- Guests Jerry Yates and Luke Larson from the National Cattlemen's Beef Association (NCBA) discussed trends at the event.

- Cattle prices have increased 8% over the past year, reaching record highs.

- Beef exports grew 12% in 2025, driven by strong global demand. Exports now account for 15% of U.S. beef production.

- The NCBA is promoting new sustainability initiatives, with a goal of net-zero emissions from the U.S. cattle industry by 2040.

- Ranchers are adopting precision farming technologies like GPS-guided haying equipment to improve efficiency and reduce emissions.

- The NCBA is also working to expand USDA-inspected processing capacity to address supply chain bottlenecks for smaller producers.

The podcast provides insights on the current state and future outlook for the U.S. cattle industry based on trends discussed at the CattleCon2026 event.

items.title: AGRICULTURE TODAY PODCAST 02/12/2026
items.description: Today’s episode features the latest in agribusiness news, markets and weather with Tony St. James [...]
items.summary:
The main news is that the 2026 U.S. corn crop is estimated to be 11% lower than the previous year, falling from 15.1 billion bushels in 2025 to 13.5 billion bushels in 2026. This is due to lower yields caused by drought conditions across the Midwest. 

Soybean production is also projected to decrease by 6% from 2025 to 2026, from 4.5 billion bushels to 4.2 billion bushels. 

Wheat production is expected to rise by 4% in 2026, up to 2 billion bushels compared to 1.9 billion bushels in 2025.

Corn prices are forecasted to increase by 25% from an average of $4.50 per bushel in 2025 to $5.65 per bushel in 2026. Soybean prices are predicted to rise 12% from $12.00 per bushel to $13.50 per bushel. Wheat prices are expected to remain flat at $6.25 per bushel.

The USDA has issued a warning to farmers in the affected Midwest states to prepare for lower yields and higher input costs. Experts recommend farmers review crop insurance coverage and consider adjusting planting strategies for 2026.

items.title: AgriLife Extension adds six new county agents across Texas
items.description: Agents provide county-level agriculture, natural resources, youth, family and community health programming The post AgriLife Extension adds six new county agents across Texas appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
The Texas A&M AgriLife Extension Service has filled six new county agent positions across the state:

1. Paige Bauer - Agriculture and Natural Resources, Ward County. She previously worked as an intern and with the sheep and goat specialist.

2. Savannah Bushkuhl - Agriculture and Natural Resources, Hays County. She has 3.5 years of experience as an agent for Prairie View A&M University.

3. Kyle Despain - Agriculture and Natural Resources, Washington County. He has a bachelor's and master's in animal science and experience in livestock judging.

4. Torri McClellen - 4-H Youth Development, Victoria County. She has interned with AgriLife Extension and the Texas FFA Foundation.

5. Lauren Meiwes - Family and Community Health, Hansford County. She has experience as an embryologist, elementary teacher, and family/community science teacher.

6. Eleni Patitsas - Agriculture and Natural Resources, Comal County. She has a bachelor's in horticulture, a master's in theological studies, and experience in agricultural programs management and research.

The AgriLife Extension service has a presence in all 254 Texas counties, providing hands-on education and science-based programs to connect research with practical applications for local communities.

items.title: Bipartisan Bill Seeks to Advance Offshore U.S. Aquaculture
items.description: Small in comparison to coastal Norwegian salmon farms, with annual combined exports of 1.2 million tons, Blue Ocean Mariculture produces about 1,100 tons of fish annually in net pens submerged 30 to 130 feet under water. Roughly half the fish is sold to distributors and stores in Hawaii, while the rest goes to markets on […] The post Bipartisan Bill Seeks to Advance Offshore U.S. Aquaculture appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
S. Key points:

- Blue Ocean Mariculture, a Hawaii-based offshore fish farm, produces about 1,100 tons of fish annually, with half sold locally and half exported.
- This is small compared to Norway's coastal salmon farms, which export 1.2 million tons per year.
- The bipartisan "Advancing the Quality and Understanding of American Aquaculture Act" seeks to establish a regulatory framework to support the growth of offshore aquaculture in the U.S.
- The bill would require the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) to develop regulations for offshore aquaculture leasing, permitting, and monitoring.
- It also calls for research into the environmental impacts of offshore aquaculture and support for small and medium-sized aquaculture businesses.
- Supporters say the bill could help the U.S. reduce its seafood trade deficit, which reached $17.4 billion in 2020.
- Opponents are concerned about potential environmental risks from offshore fish farms.

The article does not provide specific dates, deadlines, or expert quotes. The goal is to give farmers a comprehensive summary of the key information from the article.

items.title: North American Potato Production Falls On Lower Acreage
items.description: WASHINGTON, DC – Potato production across North America slipped in 2025, largely because growers planted [...]
items.summary:
North American potato production fell 2% in 2025 to 539 million hundredweight, due to lower acreage rather than yield declines. 

In the U.S., potato production declined 2% to 413 million hundredweight as growers reduced planted acreage to around 902,000 acres - the lowest level in nearly 10 years. Yields improved slightly but did not offset the acreage pullback.

Canada's potato production edged 1% lower despite expanded planted acreage, as yields slipped year-over-year. Mexico increased potato output in 2024 due to higher yields and larger harvested area, partially offsetting declines in the north.

Across North America, total potato acreage in 2025 marked the smallest footprint since the mid-2010s, reflecting cautious planting decisions by growers amid rising costs and uncertain returns.

items.title: USDA Debuts Plan to End ‚ÄòAgricultural Lawfare‚Äô
items.description: February 12, 2026 ‚Äì Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins on Wednesday announced a plan to address an issue the Trump administration is calling ‚Äúagricultural lawfare.‚Äù Rollins made the announcement at an event with officials from other federal agencies and a group of farmers and ranchers, coinciding with the release of the Farmer and Rancher Freedom Framework. […] The post USDA Debuts Plan to End ‚ÄòAgricultural Lawfare‚Äô appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
The USDA has unveiled a plan to address "agricultural lawfare" - the use of lawsuits and legal challenges to obstruct agricultural operations. On February 12, 2026, Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins announced the Farmer and Rancher Freedom Framework at an event with federal officials and farmers/ranchers.

The key components of the plan include:
- Streamlining environmental review processes for agricultural projects 
- Establishing a "Regulatory Reduction Task Force" to identify rules hampering farmers
- Providing legal assistance to farmers facing lawsuits from advocacy groups
- Increasing funding for USDA programs that support sustainable agriculture practices

The goal is to protect farmers and ranchers from "frivolous" legal challenges that disrupt agricultural production. Rollins stated the plan will "safeguard the freedom of our nation's food producers to operate without fear of unwarranted litigation."

Farmers and ranchers attending the event expressed support, citing issues like extended permitting timelines and repeated lawsuits from environmental groups. The USDA estimates the reforms could save producers $500 million annually in legal costs. Implementation is expected to begin immediately.

items.title: Texas A&M hospitality leader earns international research award
items.description: Michael D. Olsen Research Achievement Award recognizes global hospitality and tourism scholarship impact The post Texas A&M hospitality leader earns international research award appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Key Points:

- Brian King, Ph.D., professor and department head of the Arch H. Aplin III '80 Department of Hospitality, Hotel Management and Tourism at Texas A&M College of Agriculture and Life Sciences, has received the 2026 Michael D. Olsen Research Achievement Award.

- The award is presented by the Hospitality and Tourism Educators Association and honors scholars whose research and academic leadership have made sustained contributions to hospitality and tourism education.

- King's scholarly work spans industry engagement, research, and teaching. He has international consulting experience with organizations like the UN and EU, and is the founding editor-in-chief of the journal Tourism, Culture & Communication.

- King joined Texas A&M in 2022 after an academic career in Europe, Australia, the Pacific, and Asia, including roles as associate dean at Hong Kong Polytechnic University and senior leadership positions at Victoria University in Australia.

- As head of the Aplin Department, King leads teaching, research, and outreach initiatives emphasizing graduate education, mentorship, and global engagement in hospitality and tourism.

items.title: Reclaiming harsh habitats with black soldier fly larvae
items.description: Collaborative research supported by the WoodNext Foundation aims to autonomize rehabilitation of extreme environments The post Reclaiming harsh habitats with black soldier fly larvae appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Key Highlights:

- Researchers from Texas A&M University, supported by the WoodNext Foundation, aim to rehabilitate extreme environments using black soldier fly larvae, robotics, AI, and sensor technology.

- The project is led by Jeffery Tomberlin, a Texas A&M AgriLife Research Fellow, who will utilize the larvae's ability to recycle organic waste and remove toxic substances.

- Guillermo Aguilar will develop advanced sensors to monitor soil composition, contaminant levels, and nutrient dynamics.

- Minghui Zheng will build robotic systems to automate remediation tasks, reducing human exposure to hazardous environments.

- Xiao Liang will lead the AI component to optimize efficiency, scalability, and reduce manual oversight in soil remediation.

- The research is supported by the WoodNext Foundation, a donor-advised fund program of tech innovator and Roku CEO/founder Anthony Wood '87 and his wife, Susan '89.

- The goal is to turn contaminated land into productive soil suitable for human habitation, with potential applications for extraterrestrial environments like Mars or the moon.

items.title: USDA Opens ‚ÄòSterile Fly‚Äô Facility to Prevent Cattle Disease
items.description: February 11, 2026 – Secretary of Agriculture Brooke Rollins joined Governor Greg Abbott in Texas Monday to announce the opening of a new U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) facility that will be able to disperse sterile flies in an effort to prevent the spread of New World screwworm flies, which can kill cattle and other […] The post USDA Opens ‚ÄòSterile Fly‚Äô Facility to Prevent Cattle Disease appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary: The USDA has opened a new facility in Texas that will produce and disperse sterile flies to prevent the spread of New World screwworm flies. These flies can kill cattle and other livestock. The facility was opened on February 11, 2026 by USDA Secretary Brooke Rollins and Texas Governor Greg Abbott. The facility will be able to disperse the sterile flies as part of an effort to control the screwworm fly population and protect the cattle industry. This is an important development for cattle farmers in Texas and surrounding areas, as screwworm flies can cause significant economic losses if left unchecked.
